content.question: In an experiment, a wire with current <math alttext="I" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is placed in a uniform magnetic field of magnitude <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> directed to the right, as shown in the figure. The end segment of the wire has length <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and is perpendicular to the magnetic field. The experiment is modified so that the direction of the magnetic field is rotated <math alttext="ten degrees" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>∘</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> such that a component of the field is now directed out of the page. The magnetic field is still perpendicular to the end segment. Which of the following statements correctly describes the change in the magnetic force on the end segment of the wire?

choices.label: The magnitude will not change, and the direction will not change.
The magnitude will decrease, and the direction will not change.
The magnitude will not change, and the direction will change by <math alttext="10 degrees" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.
The magnitude will decrease, and the direction will change by <math alttext="10 degrees" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.
The magnitude will increase, and the direction will change by <math alttext="10 degrees" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: The magnitude will not change, and the direction will change by <math alttext="10 degrees" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.
